_exec_summary.SummaryText:
City of Lewiston Water Treatment Plant
Executive Summery


The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy at your Facility

All of the city's water treatment plant employees are trained in:

Chemical Transportation Storage (CDL w/HAZMAT endorsement)
Chemical First Responders Course
Use of class B chlorine repair kit
Use of Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA)
First Aid and CPR Certified

The City of Lewiston and the water treatment plant has set up an emergency response plan to minimize injury to people, property, and the environment.  This emergency plan utilizes the Incident Command System (ICS) and incorporates a three phase training cycle.  Further details on our training program are provided in the following section titled Emergency Response Program.
 
Your Facility and the Regulated Substance Handled


The City of Lewiston's water treatment facility located at 2901 Railroad, Lewiston, ID.  The water treatment plant is located on the Clearwater River.   The plant is located 1 mile west of Potlatch Corp., 120' south of the Clearwater River, .5 miles east of highway 12, and .25 miles north of a residential/industrial area.

The plant treats 2-15 Million Gallons Daily (MGD) to service the greater Lewiston area.  The population served is approximately 13,500.  Chemicals are used in the following processes:

Pre-Chlorination 
7 Chlorine

Coagulation 
7 Alum 
7 Lime

Sedimentation

Filtration

Post Lime
7 PH adjustment with lime (calcium carbonate)

Post Chlorination
7 Chlorine

Pumped into distribution system
7 Anhydrous Ammonia 

Regulated substance is 8,000-lbs. chlorine stored in four, one ton cylinders liquefied under pressure.  Operators are on duty 10-20 hours a day, 7 days a week.  One ton cylinder of liquid chlorine under pressure furnish the necessary gas/water mixture to disinfect the influent and effluent.  

Two operators are always present during the transfer of cylinders to and from storage.

The storage and dispensing areas are l

ocated in an enclosed building of masonry construction.

Worst Cast Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario

Worst Case Scenario

Two, one ton cylinders connected by a common header pipe experience a header pipe failure.  Chlorine is assumed to release at a rate of 400 lbs. per minute for a duration of 10 minutes.  This is an urban area where the endpoint extends 2.41 miles and has the potential of effecting 2,748 residents.  This data was generated with the use of the Degadis software program.


Alternate Scenario

A one ton cylinder of chlorine is ruptured while being moved into storage building resulting in a release.  Chlorine is assumed to release at a rate of 200 lbs. per minute for a duration of 10 minutes. This is an urban area where the endpoint extends .69 miles and has the potential of effecting 1,280 residents.  This data was generated with the use of the Degadis software program.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps 

The water treatment plant complies with the following regulations:  

AWWA Guidelines
ASTM Standards
ANSI Standards
ASME Standards
Idaho State Standards
Lewiston Fire Department Standards
EPA, Clean Air Act (CAA), Section 112(r)

Release Mitigation 

7 Chlorine Gas Alarm (2)
7 Enclosed Masonry Storage Space
7 Multiple Daily Visual Inspections
7 Automatic Chemical Alarm Dispatch System

Training 

7 Chemical Transportation Storage (CDL w/HAZMAT endorsement)
7 Chemical First Responders Course
7 Use of class B chlorine repair kit
7 Use of Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA)
7 First Aid and CPR Certified

Response Equipment

7 Class B chlorine repair kit
7 Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA)
7 First Aid Kits
7 Decontamination Showers

Response Procedures and Plans

7 Emergency Action Guide Checklist
7 Emergency Operations Plan 
7 Risk Management Program (RMP) Plan 


Five Year Accident History

None

Emergency Response Program

The Lewiston water treatment plant has a three-phase e

mployee training cycle.
The first phase is classroom instruction on chemical release prevention and response.  Employees learn (or refresh themselves) on the basics.  A trainer spends the time necessary to ensure fundamentals of chemical transportation storage, use of class B chlorine repair kits, use of self contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), first response, first aid and CPR certified, use of the emergency operations plan, and action guide are known by all personnel.

The second phase is to exercise the skills they learned.  This is done by having drills on specific tasks, e.g. putting on their SCBA and using the B chlorine repair kit.  Drills are conducted until all facility personnel are proficient at their tasks.

The third phase is testing the emergency operations plan and the skills that the employees learned.  This is accomplished by conducting a full-scale exercise.  During this exercise local emergency response and recovery agencies are involved.

After the third phase is completed an After Action Review (AAR) is conducted.  The AAR may result in changes to the emergency operations plan.  Once the plan has been revised, the process will start again on phase one.

The current emergency response plan consists of two documents:

7 Emergency Action Guide 
7 Emergency Operations Plan

The Emergency Action Guide is a quick action checklist that consists of emergency responders phone numbers and immediate action steps to protect life, property, and the environment. 

The Emergency Operations Plan is a detailed plan that give further considerations and steps to be taken in the event of an emergency.  
  
Planned Change to Improve Safety

Exercising the emergency operations plan in the form of a disaster exercise.  This training will incorporate multiple agencies and will be conducted annually.  
 
Become active in the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) to become better acquainted with community emergency response activities and programs.
